Yes, this is kind of Woodside thing. I'll just say that I've fallen in love with this country, as well as my family has, and I do have family issues back home. I don't want to make a meal out of this, but yesterday, I rescinded my resignation based on my fellow directors at West Australian Newspapers. And bottom line is, I'll continue on with that. I've got a few other things that I'm thinking about. I've been offered a few things. I've been offered some directorships in other companies in the ASX Top 20.

And let me just say one thing, I will never ever join a board or work in any capacity as anything that has anything competitive with Woodside. So, the bottom line is I'll do – I'll be completely away from Woodside, but I want nothing but success for this company and my fine friends out here. I really plan to become friends with my employees, and there won't be any business activity within.
Great. Thanks very much.
Next question will come from Stuart Baker of Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, Stuart.

Good afternoon, gentlemen. Getting late to place these questions, but just a question, Don, regarding the Browse and the onshore development as it's currently envisaged. Quite a lot of infrastructure there required really, marine terminals, jetties, et cetera. Does the joint venture intend to carry the infrastructure costs to launch this project in its entirety? Or is there a piece of business to be done to perhaps get some of the others, which are independently developing in the Browse to come here?

It's pretty obvious that Shell are going to do their floating thing and Inpex go to Darwin. But if this project gets built in the Kimberley, then clearly, there's a piece of land there and infrastructure that could sensibly be used by others. So, is there a negotiation to happen around that?

Yes, how we're planning to handle that, it's a very good question, Stuart. The total track, we think, can handle about 50 million tons of LNG. Half of that track has been given to the Browse JV as proponents, plus we have additional exploration opportunity. We only plan to use 12 million tons of that 25 million tons at this time.

You are correct that my construction managers and my Browse team think that the three trains are pretty vanilla. Nothing's vanilla in Australia, but if you can say vanilla, they're vanilla. The big trick there is the marine, to make sure the proper environmental footprint, make sure that we minimize dredging the breakwater, and all that has to be just as well. But that's kind of the biggest issue.

We would expect that other companies and proponents coming in, if they utilize our facilities, will have a proportional cost, backing cost to pick up their share of the portion. We don't see it as having to be a major issue. The state has been phenomenal in that respect that they're saying everything is coming to this place, and they're handling an awful lot of the issues.

So let me just say that it's something that we're very cognizant of. We're not giving a freebie for everybody. But I think it will be not too long of a time when other proponents who are moving their gas to other places will see this has a great synergistic value with us and we would encourage other companies to come visit us and work with us at Browse at the James Price Point. We think it's going to be a winner.
Okay. Thanks, Don, and all the best in your future endeavors.
Thank you, Stuart.
And our final questions from the telephone will be from Jason Mabee of RBS. Please go ahead, Jason.

Hey, Don. I'll keep it brief. I just wanted to ask in terms of Shell, I just wondered is Woodside taking a proactive approach at possibly trying to bring in a new strategic partner or is it a case of just letting Shell deal with it?

I want to reject some of the media statements that we don't have a good relationship with Shell. The Chairman and I are working very constructively and professionally with them. I can't go too far on this. It's early days, but I'll just say that I would hope that we're not surprised with the other 24%, maybe we were surprised the first time around. But I would say are we proactive? I think we're doing the right things right now and I really, really just can't go any further than that.

Okay. And then maybe just lastly, dividend policy, I guess a big jump in cash flows when Pluto comes along, but then also potentially big CapEx lump on the horizon if everything sort of comes off as planned. Can you just give us some color on where the dividend is heading?

Yes. Well, dividend is always an interesting discussion at the Board level and I would just say I have a huge respect for our Board's sensitivities towards the different type of shareholders we have. We do have a franking credit issue, but the Board spends a tremendous amount of time analyzing this and I think they get it right. They understand that we do have to recognize the past investments of our shareholders and put a return to them, at the same time, balancing the investment for growth in the future.

By the way, if this is my last time, I'll just say the Board has been phenomenal with myself and our management team, great Board. And I would say, usually the dividend discussions are the ones that I kind of enjoy the most with the Board, because they really get into it, and they analyze all different various angles of it, and I think they always come out, in my opinion at least, with the right answers.

So I think it'll be a balanced approach to the future, recognizing the shareholders have a right to a good return on their investment, as well as the best, lowest cost capital funding going forward, and using the cash flow in an appropriate way versus debt and equity raisings.
Okay. Thanks a lot.

And I guess that's it. So, I'll just say thanks a lot. We've got road shows going on in the East Coast, up Asia-Pacific, North America and also, Europe. We're looking forward to seeing everybody. I don't know how many visits we got, but I think it's a record. So, we appreciate your continuing interest in Woodside. This went long today, an hour and a half, but got a lot going on with the company. Thank you all very much.
Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. That does conclude today's conference. We do appreciate your participation and you may now disconnect.
